metadata.h1: Python For Data Science — A Guide to Plotly Dash Interactive Visualizations
metadata.description: A guide on Plotly Dash to Build Interactive Web Apps of Data Visualizations using Python for Data Science.

all_paragraphs: Greetings reader,if you’re like me, you like data.Data can tell a lot of stories when it’s properly presented.
We live in an era where people depend on data for business decisions, which is exactly why presenting data professionally will put you ahead of others.
Visualization gives you answers to questions you didn’t know you had.  — Ben Schneiderman
We can achieve this by using amazing visualizations. We’ve already talked about how you should take advantage of powerful libraries we currently have in Python.
In this write-up, we’re taking it to the next level. We’re going to talk about How to Build an Interactive Dashboard using Plotly Dash, in Python. The Dashboard can even be hosted as a web app.
Dash is the new hot kid on the block.

It is a Python framework that allows you to create amazing web applications using Flask, Plotly.js, and React.js. Dash is extremely efficient in building data visualization apps with highly customization user interface without the need to know any HTML, CSS, or Javascript.
Basically, it’s fast, pretty, and easy to learn if you’vealready mastered Python.
Dash takes away all the worries of needing to know web development, including the headaches of deploying the app. It is easily maintainable, cross-platform, and mobile-ready as well.
You can build your mobile-responsive web app in just pure python now.
I’m starting to sound like a salesman for Dash.
It is also good to know that the demand for Plotly Dash is increasing over the years. Below are the results for Plotly Dash in Google Trends over the past 5 years.
Now that’s out of the way. Let’s get into it.

Dash visualizations are based on Plotly. Hence, please make sure you have a solid understanding of the basics of Plotly before continuing on this advance guide. You can do that by referring to the article I wrote about the Basics of Plotly here.
In order to work with Plotly, you should master Pandas as well.What a coincidence.I happen to have written A Guide to Pandas as well.If you need to refresh your memory, please go through it.

Dash frameworks are separated into two parts. The first part is the layout of the app which defines the look and feel of the application. This involves everything from the style, positioning, and size of things you have on your app.
Dash uses components to define the layout.

In this block of code, we introduced the Div tag ( one of the most used ) and the dcc.Graph component.
The graph component is used to display a Plotly graph. The figure parameter is used to represent go.Figure, you can refresh your memory about it here.
Basically, you can pass any type of Plotly graph through the dcc.Graph component to be displayed on your app. You can then further customize the style of that graph in Plotly and Dash.
Now let’s make a layout for the data we have imported from Github.

In this app, we are simply visualizing the miles per gallon against the model year of the vehicles in the dataset. On a side note, we can clearly see a slight increase in MPG as the model year of the vehicle increases.
